item.title: You Have to Enjoy It a Lot
item.description:
中文版本

https://nav.al/enjoy
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

You Have to Enjoy It a Lot

Jul 31 2025

Naval: Marketing is an open problem. People try to solve marketing in different ways. Some people will create videos, some people will write or tweet. Some people will literally stand outside with a sandwich board. Some people will go make a whole bunch of friends and just throw parties and spread by word of mouth.

item.title: When You Truly Work for Yourself

https://nav.al/truly
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

When You Truly Work for Yourself

Jul 26 2025

Nivi:
From April 2nd: “When you truly work for yourself, you won’t have hobbies, you won’t have weekends, and you won’t have vacations, but you won’t have work either.”

item.title: Inspiration All the Way Down
item.description:
中文版本

https://nav.al/inspiration
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

Inspiration All the Way Down

Jul 15 2025

Nivi: Welcome back to the Naval Podcast where we post intermittently since 2020, I believe. We are going to talk about some How to Get Rich content. I’ve pulled out some tweets from Naval’s Twitter from the last year. I got a little help from SuperGrok as well, and we’re just going to go through them.

Accountability Means Letting People Criticize You

Jun 21 2019

You have to stick your neck out and be willing to fail publicly

Nivi: We finished discussing the tweetstorm. We’re going to spend some time on Q&A and discussing tweets that didn’t make it into the “How to Get Rich” tweetstorm. My first question: What are some common failures or things people typically do wrong when they try to apply this advice?

There Are No Get Rich Quick Schemes

item.title: Eventually You Will Get What You Deserve
item.description:
中文版本

https://nav.al/eventually
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

Eventually You Will Get What You Deserve

May 19 2019

On a long enough timescale, you will get paid

Nivi: We’re talking about working for the long-term. The next tweet on that topic: “Apply specific knowledge, with leverage, and eventually you will get what you deserve.”

item.title: Play Stupid Games, Win Stupid Prizes
item.description:
中文版本

https://nav.al/stupid-games
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

Play Stupid Games, Win Stupid Prizes

May 17 2019

Competition will blind you to greater games

Nivi:

When you’re being authentic, you don’t mind competition that much. It pisses you off and inspires some fear, jealousy and other emotions. But you don’t really mind because you’re oriented towards the goal and the mission. Worst-case, you might get some ideas from them. And often there are ways to work with the competition in a positive way that ends up increasing the size of the market for you.

item.title: Keep Redefining What You Do
item.description:

https://nav.al/redefining
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

Keep Redefining What You Do

May 13 2019

Become the best in the world at what you do

Nivi:
We talked about the importance of working hard and valuing your time. Next, there are a few tweets on the topic of working for the long-term. The first tweet is: “Become the best in the world at what you do. Keep redefining what you do until this is true.”

item.title: Work As Hard As You Can

https://nav.al/work-hard
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

Work As Hard As You Can

May 6 2019

Naval: Let’s talk about hard work. There’s a battle that happens on Twitter a lot. Should you work hard or should you not? David Heinemeier Hansson says, “It’s like you’re slave-driving people.” Keith Rabois says, “No, all the great founders worked their fingers to the bone.”

item.title: Example: From Laborer to Entrepreneur

中文版本

https://nav.al/laborer-tech
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

Example: From Laborer to Entrepreneur

Apr 26 2019

From low to high specific knowledge, accountability and leverage

Naval: The tweetstorm is very abstract. It’s deliberately meant to be broadly applicable to all kinds of different domains and disciplines and time periods and places. But sometimes it’s hard to work without a concrete example. So let’s go concrete for a minute.

item.title: Product and Media are New Leverage
item.description:
中文版本

https://nav.al/product-media
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

Product and Media are New Leverage

Apr 17 2019

Create software and media that work for you while you sleep

Naval: The most interesting and the most important form of leverage is this idea of products that have no marginal cost of replication. This is the new form of leverage.

item.title: Take Accountability to Earn Equity
item.description:
中文版本

https://nav.al/accountability-equity
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

Take Accountability to Earn Equity

Apr 13 2019

Take Accountability to Earn Equity

If you have high accountability, you’re less replaceable

Naval: Accountability is important because that’s how you’re going to get leverage. That’s how you’re going to get credibility. It’s also how you’re going to get equity. You’re going to get a piece of the business.

item.title: Embrace Accountability to Get Leverage
item.description:
中文版本

https://nav.al/accountability-leverage
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

Embrace Accountability to Get Leverage

Apr 11 2019

Take risks under your own name and society will reward you with leverage

Nivi:
Why don’t we jump into accountability, which I thought was pretty interesting and I think you have your own unique take on it. So the first tweet on accountability was, “Embrace accountability and take business risks under your own name. Society will reward you with responsibility, equity, and leverage.”

item.title: There's No Actual Skill Called “Business”
item.description:
中文版本

https://nav.al/skill-business
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

There’s No Actual Skill Called “Business”

Apr 8 2019

Avoid business schools and magazines

Naval:
In that sense, business to me is bottom of the barrel. There’s no actual skill called business, it’s too generic. It’s like a skill called “relating.” Like “relating to humans.” That’s not a skill, it’s too broad.

item.title: Why You Can't Hire
item.description:
中文版本

https://nav.al/why-you-cant-hire
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

Why You Can’t Hire

Dec 13 2011

There isn’t a shortage of developers and designers. There’s a surplus of founders.

The cost of starting a company has collapsed. It’s now just (minimal) salaries. For entrepreneurs, desks are free, hosting is free, marketing is online, and company setup is cheap.

Funding Markets Develop in Reverse

I co-founded AngelList because I was tired of saying no to entrepreneurs. I wanted to say instead, “yes, we can help you get funded.”

item.title: Who has time for meetings?
item.description:
中文版本

https://nav.al/who-has-time-for-meetings
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

Who has time for meetings?

Apr 10 2010

A lot of entrepreneurs assume that the initial way to engage with an investor is to insist on a meeting. It’s a relatively safe assumption that anyone on the buy side (an investor, an advertiser, an executive at a large company) receives far more requests for meetings than they can follow up on, and are constantly looking for excuses to say “no.”

For those of you going to SXSW, I’ll be on the [Seed Combinators Panel](Seed Combinators Panel) on Monday March 15 3:30pm. I’m joining [Paul Graham](Paul Graham), [David Cohen](David Cohen), [Marc Nathan](Marc Nathan), and [Joshua Baer](Joshua Baer) to talk about YStars, TechCombinators, SeedBoxes, and the like. Here’s the Plancast if you want me to “count you in.”

item.title: Y Combinator vs. Graduate School
item.description:
中文版本

https://nav.al/y-combinator-vs-graduate-school
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

Y Combinator vs. Graduate School

Feb 8 2010

Y Combinator* is the new Graduate School.

In some ways, it’s better:

  • You pay to go to graduate school. YC pays you.
  • After school, you get a job. After YC, you create jobs.
  • You repeat the works of the greats in school. YC expects you to do original work.
  • In school, you are graded on an arbitrary scale by arbitrary people. After YC, you are graded by the real world.

Some day, most schools in most disciplines will be like this.

item.title: Why You Need to be in Silicon Valley
item.description:
中文版本

https://nav.al/why-you-need-to-be-in-silicon-valley
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

Why You Need to be in Silicon Valley

Jan 17 2010

For years I didn’t believe this. I thought that you could take advantage of the benefits of Boston, Seattle, NY, Austin – cheaper talent, no echo chamber, local Universities, etc.. But I give up. I found myself telling an entrepreneur why he had to be in Silicon Valley if he wanted to succeed. Most of my points are about Consumer Internet businesses…

item.title: The returns to entrepreneurship
item.description:
中文版本

https://nav.al/the-returns-to-entrepreneurship
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

The returns to entrepreneurship

Nov 9 2009

I was at dinner the other night with a group of entrepreneurs. One told the story of a 27-year-old whiz kid whose company will likely exit for $500M – $1B – the business now being less than two years old. You can imagine the effect that this had on the brilliant, hardworking 35+ entrepreneurs in the group, who have had their share of hits, but not at that magnitude and not that quickly.

The Aging Entrepreneur

Can older people be great entrepreneurs?

Marc Andreesen has a great post on this age-old question. In part I, he’s digging through the data. Some of his observations are powerful and worth summarizing:

item.title: Introducing: Venture Hacks
item.description:

https://nav.al/introducing-venture-hacks
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

Introducing: Venture Hacks

Apr 2 2007

I know I haven’t posted recently, but I have been busy! Nivi and I are launching a new site called Venture Hacks, an entrepreneur’s guide to hacking Venture Capital. It’s a “tell all” site that helps entrepreneurs get on an even footing with their better-informed counterparts when negotiating an investment.

item.title: VC Bundling
item.description:
中文版本

https://nav.al/vc-bundling
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

VC Bundling

Dec 1 2005

Microsoft bundles its Office applications. Record Labels and Game Publishers bundle cash and distribution. Silicon Valley Venture Capital bundles Advice, Control, and Money. In lean times, you, the entrepreneur, have to buy the bundled good.

item.title: Unquantifiable Risk
item.description:
中文版本

https://nav.al/unquantifiable-risk
https://x.com/naval/status/1002103360646823936

Unquantifiable Risk

Nov 29 2005

A lot of the Web 2.0 startups getting started these days are of the variety where their risk is completely unquantifiable a priori. Mostly, these are highly social applications which require a large group of people to change their behavior slightly or to adopt a new behavior to work. The list includes peer-to-peer lending, social networks for recommending things, new group communication systems, downloadable photo sharing clients, etc. While some similar schemes have worked in the past (notably, MySpace, Flickr, EBay, Skype, Craigslist), the set that have failed are much much larger.
